Experiment Setup: {CHARACTER_0} wants to find out how the length of wire affects the brightness of a bulb. {CHARACTER_0} sets up circuits with wires of different lengths (10cm, 20cm, 30cm) but keeps everything else the same: same battery, same bulb, same wire thickness.

Experiment: {CHARACTER_0} sets up two circuits with 2 bulbs each:
• Circuit A: Bulbs connected in series
• Circuit B: Bulbs connected in parallel

Observation: In Circuit A, when one bulb is removed, the other bulb goes out. In Circuit B, when one bulb is removed, the other bulb stays lit.

Question: Why does the bulb stay lit in Circuit B?
options: Parallel circuits use more powerful batteries
In parallel circuits, each bulb has its own path to the battery
The remaining bulb produces its own electricity
correct_answer: In parallel circuits, each bulb has its own path to the battery

Experiment: {CHARACTER_0} places a ringing phone in a bell jar and gradually pumps out the air while listening to the sound.

Sound needs a medium (like air) to travel
Sound travels better in a vacuum

options: The shape of the container only
Water evaporates at the same rate everywhere

• Container 1: Covered with lid
• Container 2: Uncovered

After 48 hours, water remaining:
Container 1 > Container 2 > Container 4 > Container 3

Question: Which TWO factors increase evaporation rate?
options: Covering the container and small surface area
Air movement (wind) and larger surface area
Small surface area and no air movement
correct_answer: Air movement (wind) and larger surface area
